A young girl with her school friends were shown the dinosaurs and the museum instructor said, "These are 60 million years old." The little girl said, "How do you know?" He answered, ""because they were found in rock 60 million years old." A little later they entered where huge pieces of rock were. The instructor said, "these  rocks are 60 million years old." The same little girl said, "How do you know?" The instructor answered, "Because we found dinosaur skeletons in them." The little girl next said something amazing, "Isn't that cyclic reasoning? You said the dinosaurs were that age being in found in rock and now you say, the rock is that age because you found dinosaurs in it."  The instructor looked non-plussed for a moment and said, "Little lady you are right. I never thought of that before."

CARBON DATING PARAMETER
According to the developer of Carbon Dating, it is accurate back to the 2nd Egyptian Dynasty. Older than that he said the dates begin to "wobble".
That means that wildly differing dates start to show on the graph. The "wild dates" will start appearing as 3 yrs old or 300,000 yrs old or 50 million years or 7 yrs. Anything tested by Carbon Dating that is older than the 2nd Egyptian Dynasty might be accurate or it may not.
By looking at the "wildly inaccurate dates", we can pick and choose a date that best fits our theory.
We archeologists need recognition and FUNDING. The use of a method that is inappropriate to measure age of that magnitude is just a little deceiving.
The foot prints may very well be that old or "OLDER", but choose the correct test.

I'm skeptical. Carbon dating of a seed is not compelling data without corroboration from other data. It is already stated that the tracks come from an unusually wet period. Ancient sediments turned to mud are not a reliable measure of the strata that they are in. Not saying this is not possible, but mistakes in dating are hardly unknown. But the bigger question is, if humans were in the new world 10,000 years before we have thought where did they come from and where did they go?

I heard an Indigenous guy talking about their migration over from Asia. The standard story put forth...by white scientists--no offense guys, I'm white, too--was that they'd walked across the land bridge, but the problem is, the land bridge was not passable on foot at the SUPPOSED time of their migration, some 13,000 years ago. The story this man told is that the First Peoples actually sailed here from Asia, no less than 100,000 years ago. Yes, read that again, it's a six-digit number. The original mythos related by white people was that the Indigenous, ahem..."weren't advanced enough to do anything but walk here", which is just...lovely.
It's interesting, with that desert, though: if there's ground water so close to the surface, why doesn't anything grow there, really? You see a bunch of scrubby stuff like you'd expect in a desert, but not much else. Is it because it's salt flats, not real earth?

6:15 This is not the only example of rapid color change in an organism. Moths in cities in the late 1800s and early 1900s grew much darker as pollution turned buildings dark. Then as environmental protections came into effect over the later half of the 1900's the moths got lighter as rain washed the soot off the buildings.

Lizards are not the only bleached things you can find in the desert. One of those things is not Coke.
I was a kid I was playing with a friend near some rail road tracks. He found a Coke bottle about 2/3 full of a pale yellow liquid. He told me that is what happened to Coke if it is left in the sun.
I told him "No, that is what happens to Coke if you pass it through human kidneys.
From the look on his face I could see he didn't get what I was saying so I explained further that train engineers are not allowed to leave the cab of their train unattended even if they had to take a leak.
I said, drinking a bottle of Coke creates the need to take a leak, but it also provides a convenient way to deal with this problem in the form of an empty Coke bottle.
He got this horrified look on his face that turned to anger. Apparently it was his brother who told him about the "sun bleached Coke." and worse, his brother had gotten him to taste it. He said it had tasted horrible, but as he had never tasted piss before he did not recognize the flavor.
I felt bad for my friend. He was a nice kid, but wasn't very bright.

There are quite a few Pre-Clovis (More the 13,000 years ago) archeological dig sites around the country and rest of the Western Hemisphere. There's plenty of Youtube videos about them even. It looks like humanoids have been here for at least 30,000 years. I watched one from a researcher that claims it looks like tool making humanoids have been here for AT LEAST 40,000 years... potentially more.

But, the issue is that radio carbon dating only goes back 30-40K years and you can't get a time reading after that.

Many of the indigenous peoples from this continent have long said that the 13,000-16,000 year mark for when humans first arrived here was wrong. They insisted that they had arrived here more like 60,000-100,000 years ago, but because their histories were kept and shared orally with no written records, they were basically ignored by the modern scientific community. The fact that we’re finally finding so much physical evidence that directly supports the indigenous peoples claims makes me very hopeful that it will lead to more cooperation between the two groups. It gives me actual goosebumps thinking about what we could accomplish by combining the knowledge held by the indigenous communities with the powers and tools that modern science has given us.
